DOC.HEAD: Liver Recipient Monitored Closely
DOC.TEXT: Doctors kept a close watch Wednesday on the nation's second living-donor liver transplant recipient, who was recuperating from follow-up surgery to reduce an infection. Sarina Jones, 16 months, remained in critical but stable condition, according to Susan Phillips, a spokeswoman for the University of Chicago Hospitals. ``She's experiencing some bleeding problems,'' said Ms. Phillips, explaining that such complications are common in all liver transplant cases. Sarina received part of a liver Dec. 8 from her father, Robert Jones, a dry-wall installer from Millington, Tenn. Alyssa Smith, who was the nation's first living-donor liver transplant recipient, remained in serious condition Wednesday. Her condition was upgraded from critical but stable on Tuesday. Teresa Smith, 29, an elementary school teacher who donated part of her liver to her daughter for the Nov. 27 transplant, was released from the hospital two weeks ago. The Smiths are from Schertz, Texas. Sarina underwent another operation Tuesday to remove a small abscess from her abdomen, Ms. Phillips said. Sarina and Alyssa suffered from biliary atresia, a usually fatal congenital defect which is the leading reason for liver transplants in children.
